channel.title: Microsoft Watch from Mary Jo Foley
channel.description: What's next for Microsoft? Find out first with exclusive news and analysis from Mary Jo Foley and Microsoft Watch.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2004 Ziff Davis Media Inc. All Rights Reserved.

item.title: The Year in Review: Microsoft Opens Up
item.description: It wasn't a banner year for new Microsoft product releases. But Microsoft did get more 'transparent' in 2004.

item.title: ADV: Win an Epson L-410 Digital Camera and Energizer Compact Charger!
item.description: Energizer brings you it’s Hi-Charge Sweepstakes with your chance to win an Epson Digital Camera and Compact Charger with AA 2500 batteries, the hardest working Energizer rechargeable battery ever, so you never miss a shot.

item.title: Bye, Bye Windows 2000 Service Pack 5
item.description: Microsoft is tweaking its Windows roadmap yet again. This time, the Redmondians have decided to scrap the planned Windows 2000 Service Pack 5 and instead issue a Windows 2000 Update Rollup in the middle of next year.

item.title: Microsoft: Bring Us Your Tired, Your Cold, Your Counterfeit XP
item.description: Microsoft quietly unveiled in the U.K. last week the "Windows XP Counterfeit Project."

item.title: A New Member of the Microsoft Menagerie: 'Zephyr'
item.description: Microsoft is taking its "Watson" online error reporting metaphor to Windows Server. The result: Microsoft "Zephyr."

item.title: Microsoft 'Zephyr' To Take Error Reporting to Windows Server
item.description: Microsoft is bringing 'Watson'-style online crash reporting to Windows Server, starting with 'R2' in 2005, sources say.

item.title: What Will Microsoft Do With a New GNU GPL?
item.description: The Free Software Foundation is working on the first overhaul of the GNU General Public License (GPL) in 13 years. How will Microsoft react to the new license?

item.title: Beware of Third-Party IE Patches for MyDoom Variant
item.description: There's no word still when Microsoft will patch the Bofra/IFrame exploit that is a variant of the MyDoom virus. Some third-party vendors are developing home-grown patches, but security experts are telling users to wait for Microsoft.

item.title: An Announcement a Day to Keep MSN at Bay
item.description: On Monday, AOL announced plans to enter the e-mail storage market with a new offering from its ICQ subsidiary. At the same time, AOL is working on a new service that will integrate its AOL instant-messaging presence-awareness with Microsoft Outlook's contacts.

item.title: Microsoft and XML: How 'Open' is Open
item.description: Is Microsoft's implementation of XML that is part of its Office suite really open? That question was raised, yet again, at last week's XML Conference & Expo.

item.title: Speaking of Longhorn…
item.description: What kind of monkey wrench might open-source advocates throw into Microsoft's Longhorn plans if they manage to craft a more FUD-proof GNU General Public License (GPL) by 2006/2007? Stay tuned.

item.title: ADV: FREE WHITE PAPER: White Paper: SSL VPNs: The Challenge of Delivering Both Flexibility and Security
item.description: The anywhere, anytime remote access connectivity provided by increasingly popular SSL VPNs can greatly increase the network’s vulnerability to a range of security threats. Deadly attacks can be launched from unsecured or compromised SSL VPN endpoints, so it is essential to ensure their security before granting them network access. Most important, because network-based SSL tunneling can bypass perimeter security, it exposes the network to many of the same threats seen at the perimeter. A comprehensive solution is available from Check Point Software Technologies Ltd., which offers a family of products for secure remote access, intranet and extranet VPNs.

item.title: Looking (Way) Ahead to Longhorn Server
item.description: There won't be just one Microsoft Longhorn Server. Instead, there will be nearly a dozen customizable variants, partners say.

item.title: Ed Black Gets Flack
item.description: Several published reports claim that one-time Microsoft critic and CCIA head Ed Black has pocketed a hefty percentage of the $20 million that Microsoft doled out to the CCIA in order to convince the organization to cease its antitrust lobbying efforts against the company.
